metadata.title: Parkinson’s Disease  Occupational Therapy
anatomical location body part affected: Parkinson’s disease (PD) results from a disruption in the production and transport of dopamine in the basal ganglia leading to degeneration of the substantia nigra (specifically pars compacta area) in the brain and causing a wide variety of physical and cognitive symptoms(1)
description: PD is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder; most common symptoms include resting tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and gait dysfunction.(1) Pain is often also present; often an aching pain in the affected limb(s)(48)

Hoehn and Yahr Staging of Parkinson’s disease(2) –Stage 1 – unilateral movement-related  symptoms; no or minimal functional impairment, resting tremor –Stage 2 – midline or bilateral movement-related  symptoms that typically improve in response to medication; mild functional impairment (trunk mobility, postural reflexes); balance remains intact –Stage 3 – balance impairment during walking or standing; mild to moderate functional impairment, but typically the person remains physically independent –Stage 4 – motor symptoms are advanced and severe; increased balance impairment during standing or walking; moderate functional impairment (manipulation, dexterity) and unable to live alone; changes in speech and swallowing become evident –Stage 5 – wheelchair or bedbound; needs total assistance;disease is fully developed

reimbursement: No specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified
presentation signs and symptoms: Tremor –Resting tremor (often of one limb) and 4-6 Hz(1) –Tremor that disappears with volitional movement(1) –Pill-rolling  tremor in hand(1) –Tremor that occurs in jaw, chin, lips, and tongue(1)
Rigidity – “cogwheel” – variability between free movement and resistance during passive range of motion (PROM) of limbs(4) or “lead pipe”(i.e., continuously rigid)
Masked facies – reduction of facial movements and facial expression(5)
Hypophonia – soft monotone speech(5) or mumbling(1)
Decreased neck and trunk range of motion (ROM)(6)

Oculomotor/visual dysfunction(6) –Saccadic eye movements – decreased ability to look rapidly from one place to another –Smooth eye pursuits –Oculomotor muscle control – effortful eyelid opening, reduced blinking, involuntary spasms of muscles of the eyelids and brows –Convergence insufficiency/diplopia –Color and contrast sensitivity –Upper field visual deficits –Blepharitis – inflammation of the eyelids
Respiratory problems(7) –Difficulty in coordinating respiratory muscles –Dyspnea – shortness of breath  –Coughing
Decreased executive function: attention, planning, cognition(7)

Dysphagia – difficulty swallowing(7) –Some swallowing difficulties may be related to “lingual pumping,” which is associated with incoordination and food entering the airway and may be seen more with thicker consistency foods(61)

Cognitive deficits –There is a range of cognitive involvement with PD, from minimal impairment to dementia(48) –Approximately 20-30%  of Parkinson’s have dementia and an additional 30-40%  have cognitive impairments that are measurable(60) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Physical restraints (including gait belts) used to prevent falls must be used with extreme caution and should not be used as an alternative to direct supervision. Death or serious injuries may occur(40); follow facility protocols for fall prevention/ restraint use and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient

Impaired cognition and attention should be taken into consideration when providing treatment(7) –Keep instructions simple –Reduce background distractions –Ensure adequate supervision –Provide repeated demonstrations of treatment activity –Provide attentional cues –Ensure time for practice of new tasks

causes: Mutations in genes–  the following genes have been associated with PD: LRRK2 , P ARK2 , P ARK7 , PINK1 , and SNCA ; about15% of patients with PD have a family history of the disease(8)
Onset of symptoms before age 50 has been more closely linked to mutations and investigated in these genes: MAPT,HLA-DRB5, BST1, GAK as well as SNCA and LRRK2  (1)
Alterations in certain genes do not cause PD but may increase the risk of developing PD: GBA  and UCHL1  (8)
pathogenesis: Lewy body or pale body presence or Lewy neuritis(1)
Neurons that contain dopamine (major inhibitory neurotransmitter for neural pathways) are depleted in the substantia nigra,pars compacta area(1)
This affects the basal ganglia, which provides motor cues to the sensorimotor area of the brain in the preparatory phase ofmovement(6)
Due to decrease of dopamine, the motor system is in constant state of excitation, resulting in muscle rigidity(6)
risk factors: Neuroinflammation may contribute to pathogenesis of PD(10)
Sex – more common in men than women(7)
Age – more common in persons over 50 years of age(7)
Family history of PD or tremors(1)
Inadequate intake of vitamin B6 may increase risk of developing PD by 50%(11)

overall contraindications precautions: Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall prevention strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall prevention strategies
Fall risk is increased in PD beginning in stage 2. Persons with advanced PD have a high incidence of falls (40-70%).(12)
If patient is in advanced stages, with poor mobility, clinicians should observe for decubitus ulcers, contracture, or pain(13)

Document the presence of dysphagia; note any diet or thin liquid restrictions. Patients with PD commonly have cardiovascular and autonomic nervous system dysfunctions, including orthostatic hypotension, decreased heart rate, sweating disorders, urinary and bowel dysfunction, lightheadedness, weakness, and syncope

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document how long the patient has been having symptoms. How long since diagnosis? In what stage of PD is the patient? How rapidly is the PD progressing?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Surgical interventions(typically reserved for patients who are unresponsive to medications) Deep brain stimulation (bilateral subthalamic nucleus or globus pallidus interna)(1) Pallidotomy(2) Thalamotomy(2) Tissue transplants(2) Stereotactic ablation of areas of the brain to improve tremors(7) Hospitalizations Leading causes of hospital admission for persons with PD are injuries/fractures, infections (pneumonia, urinary tract infections), complications of PD treatment, psychiatric disturbances, and circulatory and digestive problems(13)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Are they effective? Ask about side effects of medications. Common side effects include nausea, gastrointestinal symptoms, drowsiness, confusion, hallucinations, psychosis, and motor dyskinesia.(5) Ask patient about when/how often he or she takes medications, as getting medications on time is important(14) Dopamine replacement(48) Levodopa(1)  50% of patients taking levodopa will develop dyskinesias after 5 years(15) Carbidopa (Sinemet)  levodopa in combination with carbidopa is typically effective for relief of symptoms of PD, but levodopa is not usually used in a newly diagnosed patient, as there is a loss of efficacy of levodopa within 35 years after start of medication(5) Dopamine receptor agonists Bromocriptine(15) Pramipexole(15) Ropinirole(15) Pergolide(4) Injectable apomorphine(15) Anticholinergic drugs Benztropine(4) Trihexyphenidyl (Artane)(5) Amantadine (Symmetrel)(5)  Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) Rasagiline (Azilect) Selegiline (Eldepryl)(5) Catechol-o-methyltransferase (Entacapone)(16,48) Bromocriptine (Parlodel)(5) Pergolide (Permax)(5) Antitremor medications(5) Propranolol Primidone Benzodiazepines (e.g., clonazepam) Gabapentin Botulinum toxin injections Coenzyme Q10 may slow progression of PD(11)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed
Diagnosis is usually made based on assessment of clinical signs: bradykinesia and one of the following: rigidity, postural instability, tremor at rest(7)
Positron emission tomography (PET) scanning may detect abnormalities in patients with PD in early stages(4,59)
Single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT), which use dopaminergic tracers, may be useful in imaging the brain(4,59)
The recommendations for genetic testing in PD made by the European Federation of Neurological Societies include:(59)
Testing for alpha-synuclein  (SNCA)
Leucine-rich  repeat kinase 2 (LRRK2)
Glucocerebrosidase (GBA) mutations for typical PD
Parkin, PINK1 and DJ-1  testing for counseling with early onset
ATP13A2, PLA2G6, and FBX07 may be considered in very early onset with no parking, PINK1, or DJ-1 mutations present
Authors of a review of developments in the early diagnosis of PD found that the following may have potential for early detection:(17)
Olfactory screening may detect early PD, as olfactory dysfunction is present in more than 90% of patients,(17) but cannot assess disease progression(59)
Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behaviors disturbances
Cardiac functional imaging
Cerebrospinal fluid and serum tests
Transcranial Doppler ultrasonography
Differential diagnosis for PD versus atypical parkinsonian syndrome
Early diagnosis(59)
Assessment of people at risk for PD(59)
Radiolabeled tracer imaging
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help Document patient’s diet;sometimes patients with PD will try a low-protein  diet to lessen motor symptoms.(18) A ketogenic diet, consisting of a high intake of fatty acids and a low intake of carbohydrates, might improve motor symptoms in some patients; however evidence is inconsistent.(18) It is important to note, however, that large, highfat meals can slow digestion and interfere with medication absorption(1)  The results of a small (15 PD patients and 44 healthy age-matched  controls) pilot randomized controlled clinical trial (RCT) designed to assess the efficacy of electroacupuncture therapy in PD showed that electroacupuncture improved “mentation,” behavior, mood, ability to complete ADLs, and balance as well as decreasing falls(52)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had speech, occupational, or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful. What education about PD has patient received?

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document what brings on or eases symptoms (and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms come on or are eased). Note the ramp up/wearing-off  cycle of medications that may bring on symptoms(19)
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much). Pain can be present as a result of muscle rigidity(20)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. -Medications for PD may have a ramp up/wearing-off cycle effect; ask patient about when he or she feels best(16)
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night, any sleep disorders patient is experiencing.(7) Thirty percent of patients taking dopamine agonists report “sleep attacks,” which are episodes of sudden, irresistible, and overwhelming sleepiness.(15) Ask if patient falls asleep during conversations, while eating, or while driving.(15) Sleep fragmentation may occur due to difficulty with bed mobility or nocturnal dystonia(12)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: Document any dyspnea or supplemental oxygen used Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes __ No __ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Is there a history of any other neurological or motor condition? Is there a history of tremor? Any history of dementia, cognitive impairment? For patients with cognitive changes or dementia including caregiver/family member in the interview may be appropriate
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, etc. Patients with PD are at increased risk for osteoporosis and osteopenia, have a lower bone mineral density and are at an increased risk for fractures(50) Associations found in a systematic review and meta-analysis  of 23 studies on PD. The search included published literature through September 2012
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing. Depression and social isolation are common in persons with PD.(5) Cardiovascular and autonomic nervous system dysfunctions are also common, including orthostatic hypotension, decreased heart rate, sweating disorders, urinary and bowel dysfunction, lightheadedness, weakness, and syncope(7)

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document patient’s work and/or leisure activities. Identify if there are any barriers to work or leisure activities
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document any use of adaptive equipment. Document how much assistance patient requires for ADLs
social and occupational history.living environment: Document patient’s living environment, such as stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Body mass index (BMI); dysphagia in PD can lead to unintentional weight loss
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assistive and adaptive devices –Assess need for adaptive equipment for self-care activities –Assess for seating and mobility needs
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance –Functional Reach Test(9) –Tinetti Balance Assessment Tool(9) –Berg Balance Scale(9) –Sensory Organization Test (SOT)(9) –Posterior Pull test subsection of the Unified Parkinson’s Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS)(9)
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Document patient’s activity tolerance and need for frequent rest breaks
6-minute  walk for distance test (6MWT) •Cranial/peripheral nerve integrity
Cranial nerve testing. Problems may be seen with chewing, swallowing, decreased facial expression, and speech(20) •Ergonomics/body mechanics
Assess patient’s body mechanics in functional activities. Note any compensatory movements, postural instability •Functional mobility  (including transfers, etc.)

Assess functional mobility within patient’s environment: home or skilled facility. Assess ADL transfers (toilet/tub/bed); note how much assistance is required, and note any assistive devices used. Assess wheelchair mobility, if applicable. Utilize FIM for objective measure(2)

Timed Up & Go (TUG) test: a test of functional mobility in which patients begin sitting in a chair and are asked to stand and walk for 10 feet(45) -In a study conducted in the United States, researchers found that the TUG test could be used to accurately predict fall risk in patients with PD(46) -Data analysis included 2,097 records of patients with PD from 16 National Parkinson Foundation Centers of Excellence(46) -When researchers adjusted for covariates, including disease severity, quality of life, cognitive abilities, and arthritis, the score on the TUG test accurately categorized over 70% of the sample as “faller” or “nonfaller”(46) -When adjusting for Hoehn and Yahr stage, researchers found that each 1-second  increase in TUG test score equated to a 5.4% increase in fall risk(46)  -A proposed cut-off  score of 11.5 was suggested as a means of identifying fallers vs. nonfallers(46)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Document gait disturbance; refer to physical therapy as appropriate for gait training –10-meter  walk test for velocity Motor function (motor control/tone/learning) –Assess for rigidity or abnormal tone –Observe patient’s movement, such as natural arm movement during walking or foot drag(23) –Observe patient’s motor skill, such as any tremor with drinking water or difficulty with shaving(23) –Box and block test(24) – assesses gross manual dexterity; consists of moving blocks individually from one compartment of a box to another within 60 seconds –Fugl-Meyer  Assessment (FMA)(24) – performance test of upper limb movement, coordination, and speed of movementgrasp, grip, pinch, and gross movement, rated on a 4-point scale ranging from no movement to movement performed normally –Purdue Pegboard Test(20) – assesses upper extremity dexterity –Finger Tapping Test(25) – assesses upper extremity coordination and movement; consists of patient tapping buttons placed 30 cm apart alternatively for 1 minute –Document the presence of motor dyskinesias
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle test muscles without abnormal tone and coordination. Muscle strength is typically reduced in patients with PD(26)
observation inspection palpation includi: Observe patient’s body positioning in sitting, lying in bed. Check for risk of contractures
If bedbound or wheelchair bound, check for skin breakdown
Skin changes may be present in patients with PD, such as seborrheic dermatitis on face and scalp(4) •Perception  (e.g., visual field, spatial relations)
Burke Perceptual Profile Screen(23)  domains include body puzzle, 3D space visualization, block design, figure ground, and fine motor planning
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Postural instability is common in PD and tends to worsen with progression of the disease(42) –Assess for any deformities, such as kyphosis(27)
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Assess active ROM (AROM), PROM, and flexibility in all extremities. Note any asymmetry or abnormalities Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –FIM(2) –Nottingham Extended Activity of Daily Living Scale(28) –Rivermead Mobility Index(28) –Modified Barthel Index(23) –Moss Kitchen Assessment Revised(23)
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: activities -EuroQol System (EQ-5D)(23) – assesses self-care, mobility, pain and discomfort, usual activities, anxiety, and depression -Health and Utilities Index II (HUI)(23) –assesses sensation, emotion, cognition, self-care, mobility, pain, and fertility -Canadian Occupational Performance Measure (COPM)(20) – semi-structured  interview of perception of performance and satisfaction in the areas of self-care,  productivity, and leisure
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Assess normal touch, light touch, pinprick, proprioception, vibration, and temperature –Patients with PD often experience moderate to severe hyposomia (decreased ability to smell)(29) –Patients with PDmay have sensory symptoms (paresthesias)(4)
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Special tests specific to diagnosis –Parkinson’s Disease Quality of Life Questionnaire 39-item version (PDQ-39)  –self-rating  assessment of patient’s self-care,  mobility, emotional well-being,  stigma, cognition, communication, bodily discomfort, and social support(2,20,23)  –UPDRS – longitudinal assessment of patients with PD in areas of mentation, behavior, mood, ADLs, and motor function(2,20) –Other quality of life measures -Sickness Impact Profile (SIP)(9) -Medical Outcomes Scale Short Form-36 (SF-36)(9)self-care,  social and personal relations, mobility, and usual
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Arousal, attention, cognition (including memory, problem solving) –Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) –Geriatric Depression Scale(2) –For communication/facial behaviors, the Behavioral Rating Scale, which rates facial behaviors, body behaviors, vocal behaviors, and verbal behaviors using videotape of patients(22) –Barry Rehabilitation In-patient  Screening of Cognition (BRISC)(23) – assesses reading, design copy, verbal concepts, orientation, mental imagery, mental control, initiation, and memory –Middlesex Elderly Assessment of Mental State(3)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Referral to occupational therapy when patient’s symptoms impact ability to function independently and safely within his or her environment
assessment plan of care.rule out: The differential diagnosis of PD includes seizures spasticity, spasms Alzheimer’s disease(4) progressive supranuclear palsy(4) diffuse Lewy body disease(4) corticobasal degeneration(4) essential tremor(4) Wilson’s disease(4) Huntington’s disease(4) multiple system atrophy(30) normal pressure hydrocephalus
prognosis: Progressive in nature, PD can result in weakness, immobility, limb contractures, aspiration of food, respiratory compromise, social isolation, depression, intellectual impairment, and dementia(5)

Patients with PD are more frequently hospitalized than persons without PD; they also have longer lengths of stay(13) –Based on a systematic review of the literature of patients with PD –Patients with PD were hospitalized 7-28%  more frequently than persons without PD –Patients with PD generally stay 2-14 days longer in the hospital than patients without PD

There is an increase in mortality in patients with PD(49) –Based on a meta-analysis  of observational studies with a follow-up  of at least 1 year  –Increased age and dementia are also associated with increased mortality
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Ophthalmology Physical therapy Speech therapy Social work Psychology/psychiatry
other considerations: Coffee and caffeine as well as a history of smoking may decrease risk of developing PD(1)
treatment summary: There is lack of evidence that carryover occurs from a nonspecific exercise to a specific task. Tasks should be practiced in the environment in which they occur(19)
Rehabilitation intervention should occur when patients are at their peak dose in medication cycle(19)

Findings from systematic reviews and meta-analyses  of the literature on the effect of occupational therapy in patients with PD are mixed(31,32,47) –Authors of a systematic review of the literature published in 2014 reported positive outcomes in patients with PD from occupational therapy(47) -Review included 55 studies; 35 articles were level I randomized controlled trials, systematic reviews, or meta-analyses; 7 were level II, two-group, nonrandomized studies; and 13 were level III, one-group,  nonrandomized studies -The review revealed three main categories of intervention: exercise or physical activity; environmental cues, stimuli, and objects; and self-management  and cognitive-behavioral strategies -Researchers found that there was moderate to strong evidence supporting efficacy of task-specific, targeted physical activity training on motor performance, postural stability, and balance. Additionally, there was low to moderate evidence suggesting that more complex, multimodal activity training supports improvement in functional movement activities. Researchers reported that there is moderate evidence supporting the efficacy of external supports during functional mobility or other movement activities on motor control. Lastly, there was moderate evidence that individualized interventions aimed at promoting participant wellness initiatives and personal control through cognitive-behavioral strategies can improve targeted areas of quality of life –Authors of a small systematic review of the literature reported insufficient evidence on the effectiveness of occupational therapy in patients with PD(31) -Three categories of occupational therapy intervention found: task-related  training, functional training with external visual or auditory cues, and multidisciplinary training -Only 8 studies were included; the author noted that lack of randomized controlled trials with large number of subjects, lack of consistency in outcome measures, and difference in intervention length and structure provides insufficient evidence on the effectiveness of occupational therapy in PD –Authors of aCochrane review of 2 studiesreported positive, but not statistically significant, results from occupational therapy(32) -Only randomized controlled studies were included -Two studies found using control groups, 84 patients in total -One study compared occupational therapy effectiveness with a control group, the other one compared group occupational therapy and physiotherapy intervention with individual intervention -Both studies reported positive effect of occupational therapy intervention; however, were not reported as statistically significant -Based on small number of patients and methodological problems with studies, authors reported that firm conclusions about the efficacy of occupational therapy for persons with PD cannot be made

Recommendations for occupational therapy intervention to facilitate “engagement in exercise and physical activity to improve performance skills and occupational performance”(58) –Strong or moderate evidence to support “Multisession, repetitive physical exercise (diachronic) to improve motor and sensory-perceptual  performance skills” –Weak evidence for “Specialized forms of exercise or more intensive task-specific  exercise (diachronic) to improve performance more than usual forms or less intense exercise” –Weak evidence to support “Single-task  interventions in a single session to improve skill development”

Outcomes are varied for occupational therapy interventions and persons with PD(33) –Based on a systematic review of the literature of rehabilitation interventions with community-based  patients with PD –Of 4 studies found with occupational therapy intervention outcomes; 1 study found under provision of adaptation and aids for the home –Two studies found significant positive effects on mobility, functional independence, and quality of life, with 1 study showing benefits being sustained over 12 months –One study found no benefit from intervention across a variety of outcomes

Using the Canadian Practice Process Framework, OT’s role in treatment of patients with PD can be viewed as follows:(55) –Enter/Initiate: Although OT often begins in intermediate or advanced PD, OT intervention may be of benefit earlier as “secondary prevention” –Set the stage: Identify occupational issues important to the patient using tools such as the COPM –Assess/Evaluate: Utilize general and PD-specific  evaluation tools to identify impairments, both motor and nonmotor –Agree Objectives and Plan: The focus should be on achievable functional goals that are important to the patient –Implement Plan: The intervention(s) provided should be patient-centered  and may focus on restoring impaired skills via training; restoring “personal factors” (e.g., routines, values, habits); improving bodily functions (e.g., motor deficits, improving fatigue and balance, increasing motivation); teaching adaptation; providing education; teaching cueing –Monitor/Modify: Utilize frequent monitoring and revise plan to keep the patient engaged. Follow the patient’s agenda, focusing on his/her key concerns –Evaluate Outcome: Determine if the OT intervention has helped the patient reach goals, improve function, and adapt to the PD progression –Conclude/Exit: Throughout the intervention focus on self-management.  Discourage dependence on the occupational therapist. Educate the patient/caregivers re: future need for additional OT intervention as the disease progresses as intermittent periods of OT intervention may be appropriate during the course of the disease to address emerging functional challenges

Patient education –A wellness course using empowerment-based, participatory-learning  approach may help build confidence and make positive lifestyle changes in patients with PD(34) -Based on study of 62 participants in a 6-week wellness course, pre and post surveys conducted -Facilitated by an occupational therapist (OT), patients and their families/caregivers participated in education program, where they set goals, shared their stories, and were encouraged to research and share information -Participants in the wellness course indicated an increase in confidence for self-management  skills and performing leisure activities -Participants reported positive changes in using mental stress management/relaxation techniques (p < 0.0129), preparing lists of questions when visiting a doctor (p < 0.011), and attending other support groups and classes (p < 0.0004)

Functional independence training –Occupational therapy intervention aimed at functional independence training may improve task performance(28) -Based on a pilot study conducted in the United Kingdom involving 39 patients with PD randomized into 2 groups: one group participated in 6 occupational therapy intervention sessions of 45 minutes over 2 months, the other was a control group -Interventions targeted specific tasks such as dressing, transfers, mobility training, through altering the environment or providing aids/adaptations -Data collected at baseline and at 2 months and 8 months after patients were randomized to groups -Positive changes were noted in the Nottingham Extended ADL Scale and the Parkinson’s Disease Questionnaire 39 (PDQ-39)  from baseline to 2 months and baseline to 8 months –Constraint-induced  movement therapy (CIMT) may improve gross and fine motor performance in persons with PD(24) -Based on a study conducted in South Korea involving 20 individuals with PD randomized into two groups: one group received CIMT, while the other group received general upper limb exercises -Both groups participated in intervention for 3 hours, 5 days/week for 4 consecutive weeks -Assessments included box and block test, FMA, and action research arm test -In CIMT group, patients’ functional arm was constrained using mitt and sling and patients were to use nonfunctional arm for: -Week 1 – folding cotton handkerchiefs, stacking plastic cups, moving set of rings  -Week 2 – transferring rice and beans, eating with fork and spoon, and pouring water from one cup to another -Weeks 3 and 4 – box to box program, eating, brushing teeth -Pretest and posttest completed 1 day before and after training -The CIMT group had significantly greater pretest to posttest changes in the box and block test (p < 0.001), FMA (p < 0.001), action research arm test (p < 0.001) –For additional information on CIMT, see Clinical Review…Stroke Rehabilitation: Constraint-Induced Movement Therapy – Occupational Therapy ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709173

Home-based,  individualized occupational therapy intervention leads to improvement in self-perceived  performance in ADLs inpatients with PD(43) –Based on a randomized controlled trial conducted in the Netherlands with 191 patients with PD (124 randomized to intervention group, 67 to control group) -The control group received medical care and could receive other allied healthcare services; however, they did not have occupational therapy during the study period(43) –Total number of sessions for the subjects in the intervention group varied depending on individual needs and goals; however, the maximum time in therapy was 16 hours over the course of 10 weeks(43) -A combination of individualized interventions was used; functional activities were performed within the home in the environment and context in which they typically occurred(43) –At the conclusion of the study, the scores on the COPM performance scale and satisfaction scale were significantly higher for the members of the intervention groupversus the members of the control group.(43) This difference was maintained in a follow-up  3 months after the end of the intervention(43)

Occupational therapy interventions are generally individualized; methods often used are practicing skills, problem solving, education, and providing environmental adaptations(3) –Based on a practice survey completed by 169 OTs in the United Kingdom –OTs reported that interventions were a median of six 45-minute  sessions over 2 months –Most commonly cited goals for occupational therapy interventions were improving functional abilities such as transfers, mobility, washing and dressing, eating and drinking, domestic tasks, and communication.(23) Other goals included home safety, leisure activities, and community integration(23)

Occupational therapy interventions should be focused on improving or maintaining function in self-care  and home skills(35) –Based on a practice survey completed by 169 OTs in the United Kingdom. Ninety-seven  percent of OTs strongly agreed that eating and drinking should be a focus of intervention. Other areas included domestic and kitchen skills (97%), washing and dressing (96%), home safety (93%), and work activities (92%)

An interdisciplinary rehabilitation program might improve gait and mobility, speech, depression, and quality of life(36,44) –Based on a study conducted in Italy with 130 patients with stage 3 Hoehn-Yahr  PD(44) -Half of the patients experienced tremor and half did not(44) -All patients in the study underwent a 4-weekintensive multidisciplinary rehabilitation treatment program that included 3 daily sessions 5 days per week. The first session involved cardiovascular warm-up, relaxation exercises, muscle-stretching  exercises, and ROM exercise. The second session was comprised of balance and gait training exercises. The third session was an occupational therapy session focusing on ADLs, functional transfers, and hand function(44) -Significant improvements were documented on all outcome measures among both groups of patients (with and without tremor): UPDRS II and III, UPDRS akinetic-rigid  score and UPDRS tremor score, Berg Balance Scale, 6MWT, self-assessment  Parkinson's Disease Disability Scale, Abnormal Involuntary Movement Scale, and Freezing of Gait Questionnaire(44) –Based on a systematic review of the literature on outcomes of rehabilitation therapy based on multidisciplinary-based approach(36) -Only 4 studies were found -None of the studies were randomized controlled studies -Results of review suggest short-term  gains in outcomes of multidisciplinary programs, but over 4-6months, the gains were not significant  -Authors found limited high-level  evidence for multidisciplinary rehabilitation for patients with PD and recommended further research –Based on an RCT designed to assess the effect of Lee Silverman V oice Therapy BIG (LSVT BIG therapy) on motor and nonmotor symptoms(53) -LVST BIG was compared to a general exercise program (treadmill and seated trunk and limb exercise) in a small (n = 11) RCT. BIG includes “large trunk and extremity functional motions” and it is recommended that it is only provided by LSVT BIG certified therapists -Improvements were seen in both groups, with no significant differences between groups -Given the small size of the study, there may be differences between the groups that were not identified. Although the study was “double-blind,” no information on blinding was provided and it is unclear how the treating therapist(s) could be blinded to intervention provided

An inpatient rehabilitation program may improve FIM scores(25) –Based on a study of 68 patients with PD admitted to an inpatient rehabilitation hospital in the United States –Pretest-posttest  design –Outcome measures: FIM, TUG test, 2-minute  walk test, and Finger Tapping Test –Patients participated in combination of physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy 3 hours/day for 5-7days/week; mean length of stay was 20.8 days –Patients participated in individual treatment sessions as well as group sessions –Interventions consisted of functional training, gait training, ROM, flexibility and strengthening exercises, and speech exercises –Significant improvements in FIM total score (p < 0.007) and TUG test score (p = 0.017)

Occupational therapy interventions that use coordination strategies may be beneficial in improving upper extremity functioning in persons with PD(37) –Based on a study conducted in the United States involving 11 patients with PD, age range 32-55  years; 7 patients with no known neurological deficits served as controls –Small sense coils were attached to upper arm over radial side to record upper arm movements in sagittal plane in reaching –Other small sense coils were attached to radial side of the nail of the index finger to record movements in the transverse plane in reaching –Patients were then recorded completing fast reaching and grasping movements without any real object to grasp (eliminating visual and kinesthetic components of movement) –Each patient performed at least 10 reaching and grasping motions –Patients with PD had both upper arm and index finger movements that were significantly slower than those of participants without PD –Patients with PD had an impairment in the spatial relationship between the upper arm and index finger movements, resulting in segmented movements –Patients with PD had poor timing, inability to finely tune the “reach to grasp” action –Results of this study suggest that coordination task training may be an important intervention focus

Feldenkrais method-based  exercise programs may improve quality of life (QoL) and improve depression(54) –Based on an RCT conducted in Brazil; outcome measures included Parkinson’s Disease Quality of Life questionnaire (PDQL), Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), and MMSE –Intervention group received 50 treatment sessions (2x/wk) which emphasized “awareness through movement” focusing on breathing, rolling over, sitting, standing, squatting, and walking –Control group received lectures over the same time period, focusing on falls prevention, medication management, and activities of daily living –The intervention group had significant improvements compared to baseline, and compared to the control group in QoL, rate of depression, and mental state score. In addition there was a positive correlation between depression and cognition in the Feldenkrais group –The study did not include long-term  follow-up,  so it is unknown what the duration of the immediate post intervention benefits would be

Auditory rhythmic cuing may improve walking speed of patients with PD(38) –Based on a systematic review of the literature –Found 24 studies, with only 2 studies being randomized controlled trials  –There did not appear to be enough evidence to establish the effectiveness of visual and somatosensory cuing –There does appear to be evidence for improving walking speed through auditory cuing

Treatment focusing on “dual task management” may improve safety during ADLs in patients with PD(56) –Based on a systematic review of the literature published in 2000 and beyond –Multi-tasking  during ambulation (as is often required with ADLs) impairs gait (e.g., decreased stride length and speed) and this may increase fall risk during these activities –Dual task gait training (DTGT) by a variety of methods (e.g., dance therapy, Wii games, use of rhythmic music) has been shown to improve gait or minimize the negative effect of multi-tasking

Tai chi may improve physical function in PD(51,57) –Based on a meta-analysis(51) and systematic review(57) –Evidence suggests that tai chi may improve motor function and balance, but there is insufficient evidence to conclude a cause and effect relationship between tai chi and improvements in PD

“Alternate” exercises may be useful in improving motor performance and quality of life in patients with PD(62) –The authors of a systematic review found that dancing, water exercise, and robotic gait training were effective treatments and there was some evidence to support virtual reality training, mental practice, aerobic exercise, boxing, and Nordic walking training in the treatment of PD . maintenance or prevention: Ibuprofen may lower risk of PD(10) Based on a study of 37,305 men and 98,892 women in the Health Professionals Follow-Up  Study and Nurses’ Health Study from Harvard University Participants completed medical history and lifestyle questionnaire every 2 years over a 6-year  period Of the total cohort, 291 PD cases were identified Ibuprofen use associated with lower risk of developing PD (p = 0.02) More tablets of ibuprofen use associated with lower risk of PD (p = 0.01) Ibuprofen users had 30% lower PD risk than nonusers

Physical exercise has been associated with a reduced risk of PD.(41) Additionally, research indicates that physical exercise(e.g., walking training, tai-chi,  tango dancing) improves disease symptoms, mobility, balance, gait, and quality of life in patients with PD(41)
